reviews.review_msg: Very frustrating when class got swapped onto online classes and she does not provide detailed notes or lectures and tell us to watch youtube videos. Then when asked for clarification TA told us to watch different youtube videos. Considering papers are written on the topics it is difficult to do well when the material is not understandable.

Very helpful and nice prof so if you don't understand something, go to her office hour! Going to class is mandatory because Michaela doesn't post her lecture notes online and her lecture slides are very important to study from if you are lazy and don't want to read the long assigned readings. There are 2 quiz in tutorial and no midterms.

Course requires 3 essays and 1 Final. He gives you the questions that are going to be on the final at the beginning of the sem! But make sure you start reviewing them early! Final was a piece of cake. He has a high understanding of phil, lectures tend to drag but if you read the text PRIOR to attending you'll get what hes talking about.

It's bad enough his lectures are boring, but its also useless.  Seriously, do not take his classes!  His notes are a buntch of chicken scratches.  Although his intrest in the course is high, he forgets that the students are NEW to philosophy.  He thinks that he is talking to Philosophy majors or something.

Let's just say I wish I took English instead. Don't expect this to be an easy elective... John has extremely boring lectures. I read the chapters before class and literally it's like he is reading directly from the book. Even the examples are the same. Then he has the nerve to get mad at students on their laptops... What a joke.. Take english folks

A friend of mine took him for logic and said he was great. I honestly had no interest in this course. He talked to us as if we were 4th year phil majors expecting us to know all phil theories and concepts. Entire grade was on essays. 5 short ones 1 long one and a final exam consiting of 8 short ones. Hard teacher
He's an amazing person but the grading scale was mad weird.

This class was a disaster. He rushes through material with no real explanations, leaving us completely lost. The TAs were no betterâ€”unhelpful and clueless about the course content. It felt like no one cared if we actually learned anything. If you value your time and education, avoid this class entirely.

Prof was very nice and easy. The TA's were also very fair markers. I would highly recommend to take this class. There are weekly assignments (easy 100%) and participation. Final paper and final exam were pretty easy too, you just have to remember repeated concepts.
Great prof, super easy to follow, engaging lectures. Assignments aren't too bad, but it depends on the TA. Easy gpa booster.

Tom was a fantastic professor! I went to the lectures just to hear him talk because he was so engaging and has a great accent. The grading is fair and assignments are pretty easy. He wrote the textbook, which is interesting but is not necessary to do well in the course. My TA (AJ) was super helpful in understanding the concepts. Highly recommend!

Truly awesome guy. Engaging lectures and clear feedback from TAs on assignments. Open to discussion and questions during class. Expect weekly assignments. He seems to really love what he does. Be aware that exact terminology for different beliefs is expected on the final-- don't be vague. Overall, great course taught by a great prof!
take him if u got the chance crodieeeeee

Literally the GOAT. My TA (AJ) was amazing - always provided good feedback and genuinely cared about us and wanted us to succeed. Tom is literally such an amazing prof and amazing person. Would 100% take another class with him. 10/10 as a dude and 10/10 as a prof.
Nothing against the prof, but horrible TA, ruined my whole grade and as long as you don't get her, you should be good.
Was an awesome professor and the lectures were very easy to follow and helped a lot

Tom is a really good prof. He is engaging and very effectively explains the topics. However, if you are put with a bad TA the class will be ruined for you. The class is based off personal opinions, but if your opinion is against what the TA wants then your wrong.

Tom is very engaging during lectures and takes a lot of questions. The weekly short questions are quite easy if you've done your readings beforehand. The first analytical assignment is short and easy, the second one is a bit longer but not too challenging.
Genuinely the textbook defenition of a good prof and a good person. He teaches well, makes sense, is clear, and conscise. you cant ask for more or better at sfu.

Tom is a really chill prof and the content is pretty interesting. When it gets a bit more confusing and heavier, later on, he does a great job of reviewing and clarifying anything. PHIL100W is a pretty simple course and can help your GPA if you put in the work and effort.
Literally the greatest prof of all time.

Great prof! His lectures are super engaging (and he's british) and he makes sure you understand each argument you go over clearly. Dr. Donaldson is super passionate and you can tell he really cares about his students! Assignment guidelines are pretty clear, grades are totally dependent on your TA tho. Overall super interesting class!

I actually enjoyed going to his lectures. He's engaging and funny and makes everyone laugh. There is a tutorial, where you just mainly discuss things from the lecture. My tutorial marked attendance, unsure about others. Overall, Tom is a great prof and the course load is not heavy. Weekly assignment + 2 Papers + Participation + Final.

While this class was required for me and im not a fan of philosophy, Tom made it interesting and an enjoyable class. He is willing to read your paper and gives great feedback to improve. Two papers, a take home final, and weekly small writing assignments so not an overload of work. Highly recommend taking a class with Tom!!

The best prof I ever had. If any of you get the chance, take class with Dr. Donaldson as he made boring phil concepts seem so much more fun. I always looked forward to attending discussions with him as he was always so engaging and entertaining. Highly recommend this prof, I'd give him 1000 stars if I could.

Tom is awesome! I took his class in my first semester at SFU and having him as an instructor made the transition into university from high school smoother. He's a great lecturer, informative and a clear voice- the fact that he's v cute doesn't hurt either. Wish I wasn't so terrible at philosophy so I could take a class with him again. Big reccomend
Really nice. Engaging. Funny guy. Highly recommend.

Tom's lecture was the first one I went to as a first year at SFU and honestly, he was so comforting and sweet that I knew I would be okay. He took the time to learn my name, and even though I didn't love philosophy he tried his best to make the lectures entertaining and engaging and hes so so nice. Also cute! He is such a genuine guy I love him

Tom is an amazing Professor. I took his class this semester and it was amazing. Also, his British accent is charming and he explains everything carefully, slowly and greatly. If anyone considers to take Phil with Tom than do it. You will love it!

I love this prof. I really hope he reads all of the feedback from rate my prof because he's truly an amazing instructor. I wish he taught more than just philosophy so I could have him again. He is straight forward and his accent is absolutely charming. He's extremely attractive and makes lectures very entertaining. He's extremely kind and helpful!

Dr Lauro makes his lectures engaging! Some of the examples he uses caught me off guard and made me pay attention when I drifted off. My TA didn't give me specific feedback on my essay draft - Dr Lauro was easily approachable and made sure my TA gave better feedback on the next assignment.

Professor Lauro explained things clearly and well, he also had a number of funny moments through his lectures. Essays were clear about what they would be graded on. My only complaint is that he talked rather fast, which I didn't mind too much, he's got a lot of slides to cover after all, and he didn't post the slides until after lecture.

Greg Lauro is an amazing teacher who answered every question I asked him was very approachable made the lectures entertaining to go to and is just a good guy. That being said he is not the one who marks your paper. I recommend going to tutorials as even though they don't give any credits your TA can suck and be very picky about writing. take again

Definitely one of the best profs I've had at SFU. His lectures are filled with sufficient examples and clear definitions of all the concepts and terms such that you don't need to take notes, just simply watch and learn. Aside from that, he's a patient prof and very calm. The essays are simple which makes it very easy to actually show what you know.
goated

The prof is good and has good lectures however your whole grade depends on your ta. I had Yanjie and he was awesome since he's super helpful and as long as you put effort into your essays he will give you a good grade. My only concern is the final didn't have a clear guideline and was harder than expected so that brought my grade down.

man the proff is great bro. stand up guy. no hate towards this man. THE TA IS THE WORST THING IN EXISTENCE. man, they make up so much bs in their grading and take months to get back a 3 pg essay and give no feedback and are so stubborn. DO NOT TAKE THE TA JACOB SCHWARTZ he will penalize u for no reason when other ta's do not.

To succeed in this course just hope you get a good TA. I would write the maximum word limit and still get a satisfactory for explanations, which is odd. They didn't explain any mistakes, but just gave me a satisfactory. I do believe I could've received a higher mark with a different TA. I regret not trying to switch TAs could've gotten a bettermark
Great new professor. He understands students and makes the class as intriguing as possible. 3 essays and 1 final multiple choice exam. Optional tutorials
Her lectures were easy to follow, the material was engaging, alot of assignments but were fairly marked 10/10 would have her as a professor again.

You really need to read the material before the class but the tutorials and lectures really help in understanding. If you show up and do the work the class isn't too bad. Just heavy on the readings, but you can easily skip some readings.

This was my first philosophy class and I enjoyed it a lot. Her lectures are interesting but I do got to admit, the material is a bit dry. The midterm and final was pretty straightforward and easy. I think what made this course more enjoyable was my TA that was extremely helpful. Ask your TA for help!! and this course won't be that bad.

Rosemary is mediocre at best during the time I've had her for PHIL100W. She's lifeless during the entirety of the lecture, giving no feel of interest towards the reading's she's given to us. Although she does make some jokes, those are unable to excuse for the bland talk behind the lecture doors. My advice: Prepare for a long day of reading.

Her lectures are not well structured and her voice is very lazy and uninterested. Although she is funny at times, her boing lectures don't really make up for it. There are lots of reading, however, the summaries are not that hard and the TA are not too tough with grading. Overall, if you want to learn, don't take this class, basically taught myself

Her lectures are very boring as her voice is monotone and uninteresting. She does not provide any grading criteria and it is very difficult to write philosophy papers without guidelines. Do not take a class with Rosemary she makes philosophy more boring than it already is.

So Simon was my first philosophy teacher and I loved it. His lectures are funny with occasional swear words, sometimes off topic, but useful for books you read in class. The SWA's weren't too bad, just need to read a lot to do well. Essays were fairly easy with feedback he gives, and you pick 5 out of 10 questions based on the books for the final
Very knowledgeable, she has interesting lectures. iClicker questions during class for credit. It doesn't matter if your conclusion is wrong, as long as you defend it.
This is too difficult for a 100 course. Her lecture is not high-quality compare with what she expected to her students. Do not take her class.

Where to begin... PHIL 100W requires class attendance because she makes iClicker questions and some of the material from class discussions ends up on the midterms and finals. The term papers are very hard to get a good mark on. Average of the class for the midterm was 16/31. Tutorials didn't help at all, made the material even more confusing.
less explanation in the notes. hard to understand the concept . hard midterm and tough paper marker

This is probably one of the worst profs I've ever taken. She does not test for knowledge on the exams, and on top of that they are way too hard for a 100 course, yet alone any course. Theres a reason why the course average on midterm was well below 50%. I would DEFINITELY try to avoid this prof at all costs. Nice person, but HORRIBLE TEACHER!
DO NOT TAKE IT. I REPEAT. DO NOT TAKE IT.

Her lectures are interesting, but her tests are ridiculously hard. She tests random little details, and won't ask about things that we spent multiple lectures on. On the written, she'll deduct marks for not writing certain things EVEN THOUGH IT IS NOT ASKED FOR IN THE QUESTION. I had a good grasp of the material but her tests didn't let me show it.

loved it! she shows interest in the material, engaging, interesting topics, thought provoking, clear but challenging notes/lecture - it is hard material if first phil course so take time each week to understand the material. Found it useful to listen to the recorded lectures online. Quick to post notes online. she is condescending though at times.
she is a good teacher
She is quite interesting and can make lectures fun! However, her marking is tough! You definitely need to take notes in class and really understand the content.

I loved her class. At first I was a little weary -she seemed very specific and particular, however I realized she was only setting ground rules so the students would know what to expect from her, and it really did gain respect from the class. She is an excellent prof -her lectures were always engaging, witty, and interesting. Thank you dr Mc!
Everything you need to know for the tests are covered in the lecture.  If your new to philosophy might be a bit rough.  Take notes, review them often.
Pay attention, take your notes and study them, everything on the tests is covered in class.

She makes the content really confusing and expects you to know a lot beforehand. Also, her papers have ridiculous topics and she is really picky about citing. She'll consider it plagiarism if you use a different kind of referencing style, but she doesn't give us an exact paper style to follow.

If you're good at math and logic, want to be a lawyer or doctor, then I recommend this course. However, it's a hard course. The prof isn't clear about her teachings, lots of examples but definitions are very unclear. Marking scheme is unfair. TAs care more about their work than students needing help. Prof is kind of patronizing and out of her mind.

Horrible course! Never take this esp as a B-Hum credit because your CGPA is likely to get negatively affected. TA's don't give good grades, they expect totally out of the blue stuff from you on the midterms and essays! If you are an A grade student, then DON'T take this course, it will only give you heart attacks, no matter how hard you study !! :/
midterm is easy, final is hard. go to lectures and pay attention and you will do well.

She's alright. Study the Slides, READ the material. I mean really READ. She will ask you things like what is the Knowledge Argument? What is the Modal Argument? These are all questions from Epiphenominal Qualia.

The course material is boring and ambiguous coz it's philosophy. If you actually ever go for her office hours, she is really helpful and gladly understands your point of view. She is NOT condescending. Second paper's 1 revision was due early to give us more time for final revision, which is better in my opinion. Midterm was cakewalk.

Totally and completely unorganized. The second paper was due before she was finished teaching the topic. The textbook was totally useless, used the first chapter and that's it. She moves really fast through the slides and puts a lot of text on it too. May or may not upload slides online. Midterm was ambiguous, TA's are more confusing than helpful.
Lectures aren't well coordinated and don't flow well, information is very fragments and topics seem to skip around. Keep on top of the readings to do well in the essays and you'll do well.

I consider myself blessed to have been her student. Not only is Dr. Mc an outstanding lecturer, she is capable of tremendous empathy--she is among the most compassionate people I know. It was a pleasure to be in her class and it is still always a pleasure to talk with her and bask in the warmth of her presence. I love Dr Mc. To me, she is flawless.

midterms and finals are really hard, not a GPA booster like you would expect, material is definitely interesting but the requirements are way too high for just a first year phil course. don't take if you think it will be an easy class to boost your GPA

Lectures were boring though you can clearly see how enthusiastic the prof is. Material was dry and incomprehensible most of the time. Asking the TA didn't help at all. The papers were odd and difficult to write to get a good mark. Midterm was VERY DIFFICULT, and dreading the Final tomorrow.. Horrible class. Do not take unless you have to!

Professor Mc is not the best lecturer, she left the whole class confused many times at the end of lecture and often rushes her thoughts near the end of class. The midterm was pretty difficult and unfairly marked. My TA was also extremely unhelpful. Unless you have real interest in Philosophy, DON'T take this course!

A lot of people seem to dislike her, but I find her explanations quite clear. The midterms are fair, and easy if you attend lecture. If your not a critical thinker then you'll probably flunk out and end up blaming her. The TAs are good too.
she is simply horrible. she makes the concepts harder than they really are. Does not teach very well, and is VERY boring. I would avoid this professor at ALL costs.
She is a very good prof that knows what she's talking about.  I just think I was not compatible with the course itself.  Notes were good but the actual course was so confusing.
She is good at what she does, but the course material is just awful ( p then q then p then not p then p then p). Paper topics are strange but the T.A. is a good help.
No Comments

Professor Manson was a very good instructor IMO. She encouraged questions and interaction with students during her lectures which made them engaging. She referred to slides, not read verbatim, but used as prompts. All testing in-class, so felt fair. Heavy reading load and not a "read and regurgitate" course, but mind expanding if engage seriously.

Dr. Manson only reads off her slides and doesn't provide clear instructions of what her exams will be. There is not assignments outside of class as all her exams are in-person either in class or in tutorials. She often asks her students to answer questions but if you answer wrong she answers in a passive aggressive manner. Wouldn't take again.
Absolutely the worst class I have ever taken in my life. This is class is bane of my existence. I dont ever wanna have a single philosophical thought because of this course.
This class is cooked do not take it

Her lectures are very engaging, and she usually asks questions to the class to keep people engaged. She can seem a bit intimidating. I only dropped this course because the TA I had was a really tough grader, especially with wording. All of the assignments are done in class.
Lecture presentations on class information is very unclear.

oh my god, i really don't know where to start. She is so boring. The things she says in class are pointless! She likes to talk about things you have access to. Talks really slow and doesnt focus on aspects we should know. I think you should just consider this course a distance ed, stay home and read the powerpoints! Waste of a professor!

Jay made Philosophy super interesting! 3-hour lecture always feels like a 30-minute lecture and he is really hilarious. He is caring and reachable! Midterm was fair as long as you study and actually understand the materials, in class writing for attendance but it is all based on your opinions and thoughts. There's no correct answer.

No group work, records lectures, tries to be as thorough as possible in the 50 minutes given. Lectures are well thought out, her teaching ability is amazing if you pay attention. Gives the general gist of what the philosophers are talking about, but honestly your grade will mostly depend on which TA you get. Get Anthony if you can.

Records lectures which is nice. Goes over everything you need to know about the readings and only tests from what she talks about in lecture, but being familiar with the readings is a must. Get Anthony as your TA, he's the nicest guy and incredibly helpful, and I would not have done as well without him.
She only has 30 minute office hours and that shows how little care she has for her students. Her midterms are extremely impractical and they test you on the most pointless topics.

Dr. Warriner is really nice and gives fascinating lectures. She encourages questions and gives helpful and in-depth answers. The class is quite difficult, though, and it's important to actual understand the material rather than just memorizing the slides for the exams.

Dr. Warriner is amazing. She is very accessible for help and gives in-depth responses, even over email if you are unable to make her office hours. The two papers written in this class are fairly graded as well. However, although the content is interesting, prepare for it to be difficult. If it wasn't for the prof, I would not of enjoyed the class
One of the best profs by far at SFU. She knows what's she's talking about and will give you that extra help that you need if you're not clear on a certain theory. Highly recommended.
Just painful.  She talks so incredibly slowly so I downloaded the recordings of the lectures online and sped them up by 25% just to make her bearable.  Assignments are fairly difficult as well.

Lectures were good, paper assignments were okay. Main criticism is the final. It was awful, as we were told that we could rely on the help of the notes, but the questions given were not related to what was presented to us. I guarantee that the average is low.
Awesome prof. His lectures were straightforward but he goes very fast. Would take another course with him again!!

Martin's teaching style is very casual. He also tends to go through the slides very quickly. Be sure to bring a laptop to his lectures if you want to quickly jot things down. If you have a genuine interest in philosophy, you'll enjoy his class. Very little homework. The open book final was heavily based on comprehension and not memorization.

A very easy mark. I accidentally did my homework and was good to skip 3 weeks of lectures, where the same material was mulled over. Martin doesn't take this class too seriously, hence the tone of the lectures. Make sure to befriend your TA - all real marking is done by them. Exam is open book, so print the notes and major readings the night before,

This is an easy course to get a moderate grade and there is not much work in this course. The final is open book and easy. Two short papers in this course. The only thing i don't like is that you may need to read the textbook for the tutorial's short writings.

He can be a little difficult to understand at times, but he really does put in the effort to deliver an understandable lecture with many examples to explain the concepts! He is passionate about what he is teaching. He seems very friendly and likes to laugh. Overall a really cool professor.

He's a good professor! He discusses different topics for each class which are also related to the weekly reading assignment. He is cool and encourages students to ask questions in class. Seems very interested in philosophy!

Horban is a great lecturer, with a very pleasant voice.  His exams are tough, but in answer to other complaints, he warns repeatedly before an exam how the papers are to be handed in and in this matter he is absolutely inflexible.  The best prof I had this semester, will definitely take another class with him
Horban is a great lecturer, with a very pleasant voice.  His exams are tricky, and you are required to follow his instructions exactly, but he's fair.

He is clear because he reiterates himself a lot more than necessary, and leaves 7 second pauses between every sentence. That said, you must be patient or you will be very annoyed. Lecture notes in class is basically his speech/what he says in class. Expect to be comparatively more distracted than other classes.

Very lucid teaching. For people who already know a bit about philosophy, his slow pace can be quite a pain, but this really benefits everyone else. The course does not cover a lot of material so it's easy to keep up with the reading. The course is really about the understanding of several "-ism"s, which if you do it's easy. Otherwise, work hard.

Dr. Andersen is okay. Her lectures are quite helpful in understanding the content, but she uses very pretentious and unnecessary language in explaining the content which is a bit unhelpful. Her tests are very fair though. Overall, not the worst prof.

She is the best professor I've ever had. Her lectures are interesting and very clear. She explains the readings so well and with such ease that you will completely understand them once you go back and read them again with her explanation. Midterm and final were fair. Best. Prof. Ever.

Everyone seems upset by the final, but the reason it was made so hard was because the department has guidelines regarding what students should be getting, so she had to balance it with the easy midterm.  ANYWAY.  I think she was a great prof.  Some of the readings were challenging, but being a philosophy course, one should expect to be difficulty.

She gave decent explanations of the material and posted all lecture slides online which was very helpful for studying for the final. As long as you actually do the readings for this class (which many people didn't) it is not too difficult.

I don't have a problem of calling her "doctor", people work hard for a PhD, I can understand that. However, she is definitely not as approachable as most profs and can really get in your face unpleasantly. Had more luck on papers than doing the final, TA was a lot more generous and helpful even if tutorials were more or less a recap of lecture.

Doesn't help much in class since her answers to every question is irrelevant. Why would a prof go out of the way to make the average 40% AND THEN curve it. Also, she won't respond to everything BUT doctor andersen since she has a phD in philosophy (also a mistake) I'll call her a doctor when she can medically aid in someone's health.

The final was closed book reading comprehension that was never even talked about in class. Papers marked hard. If you need to lower the average, make the course harder or add a paper; don't just make the final ridiculous..I bet TA's would of failed...ruined Philosophy for me and I worked really hard for a C+

She definitely doesn't know how to teach.Average was 39% for this semester and C average for papers,What do you expect to end up with? Bingoo!! C grade.Avoid this prof even if you have to change your school.she basically wants everyone to fail or get C Grade.She has something for Doctoral degree as she asks people to call her with her Dr thingie.
Midterm was not hard and average was high. However, pro was unhappy with that results and aimed to make the final average around 40%. That's why I ended up just with B- .....(
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH THIS PROF. SHE IS ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE. DOES NOT EXPLAIN THINGS WELL AND WANTS STUDENTS TO DO POORLY. FINAL EXAM AVG WAS 40%.

dont recommand her class because she grades hardly. She aims an avg of 45% for the final exam which is 25% of the overall grade. 50% overall for two papers and class avg for the papers were around C range. Midterm was simple. If you planning to take her course, be prepared.
hard for esl, not good at explaining at all. do not take this class unless it is required
One of the worst profs I've ever had at sfu. If you take her you will regret it.

The lectures were very informative with helpful and relevant content. Philosophy in itself is hard so the papers (the levels) were a bit difficult for me. There are lots of readings but he goes over the majority of them in class which is very helpful. Uses good examples in lectures.

He's a good guy, I liked my TA too which helped. Lectures I found it quite dry though, if I didn't drink before lectures, I would be incredibly bored. So I didn't attend many, easy B-. I was at A- in levels before final paper and exam, so I really bombed those.

Prof. Heide was a good lecturer and explained the readings and related concepts well. That said his exams were a lot of work. His assignment grading scheme is difficult and unusual to get used to. Was available during office hours.

If you hate writing, don't take this course. If you hate reading (especially confusing philosophical things), don't take this course. Actually, I hate both, skipped class and tutorials biweekly, yet I still passed so I don't know. Your TA is more significant for this course since they mark everything (mine was Jing-Hwan, 10/10 chill dude).

One of the best lecturers Ive had at SFU. Down to earth, thoughtful course curriculum, and knows his material inside out. Course was very interesting and challenging in all the ways you want from a philosophy course. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE FOR AN EASY ELECTIVE. You will fail. Put the time in, and youll love this course.

Dai Heide's grading system is tough and unforgiving. There was way too much material for the course to be an intro level philosophy course. His explanations were mediocre and oftentimes felt overcomplicated. The "levels" assignments portion of the course took up most of the semester and was only worth a 30%.
The readings are super long and confusing, but if you go to lectures and tutorials you'll understand them. The lecture slides really help as well. Assignments and final were fair.

Lectures were engaging and the material was super interesting . If you are interested in learning about personal identity, immortality or the meaning of life this class is for you! Readings can be confusing but lectures and tutorials were super helpful! For the final he gave us 16 short answer questions in advance, and 5 were on the test.

This class is very tough for an intro class, there are "levels" assignments, you must pass the first level in order to start the next "level" and its difficult. there is a term paper and a final, together worth 70 percent of your grade at the end of the semester so only 30 percent is determined throughout the major portion of the semester.

I took Phil100W & Phil150 with him during Covid online & it was a breeze. I didn't even read all the material(cause there is a lot) & I got through with a B+ in both classes. The final exam consisted of essay questions, a week before he gave us a list of 16 questions & of those, 4 questions would be on the test. he also let us pick our test day.

very accommodating to online learning. i found his lecture slides to be super helpful and they helped explain the readings. asynchronous lectures so no real weekly schedule to follow just make sure you dont fall behind because theres a lot of reading and writing. overall great class!
With a voice like that, I would follow this man unto the depths of Valhalla and back.

You can tell that he's genuinely passionate for philosophy, I enjoyed going to his lectures, but not gonna lie, I was probably confused half the time (as interesting as they were), going to tutorial after really helped cleared things up.

A great prof! Lectures were very clear and helpful. Seems to genuinely care about students. Does a great job answering questions. Made difficult topics much more understandable and interesting! Lots of reading in writing but he made it enjoyable.  Overall, I really liked him as a prof and would definitely take his class again!

He's honestly one of the more interesting profs at SFU I've had. Clear, cohesive lectures summarize the reading material well. Dai's voice in lectures is amazing and captivating. Exams are tough - study hard and you'll do better than average! Class was graded on a bell-curve. Overall, an interesting course, taught by an equally interesting prof.
love him. if u work hard u can get a good mark. No matter whether English is your 2nd language or not.Final is fair for who really study.
Took both Phil xx1 & 100w with Dai. Extreme Hotness that draws your attention.The only drawbacks are his speed of talking and brutal exams.

Second straight semester taking classes with Dai. Amazing professor, I love the style he teaches, very clear at explaining everything, and gives great real life examples. Don't be expecting to get an easy high mark though, Philosophy is one of the hardest departments in SFU
He's a very good teacher, did well in the course, but he's an ass.

I personally found Dr. Hahn to be an enjoyable lecturer and attended all his classes. I did feel like the philosophy was fairly one sided focusing primarily on Greek thought. It would have been cool to learn about other practices. The paper was a breeze and final was difficult but not impossible. He curved the final though so decent class average.

Literally reads his slides word for word so do not bother going to lectures, it will make you dislike the topic a lot more. I'm lucky to have a great TA so i can talk to them about questions that he was unable to answer in class
Bro showed up with covid, but don't worry he only coughed into his mask :)

Overall Martin was a good professor simply because he was passionate about what he was teaching. I found that the grading was quite strict but tutorials were a big help when writing his papers. The final exam was also graded pretty strictly.

Boring lecturer. Reads off slides and doesn't add anything new. Don't attend his lectures waste of time he posts slides. Make sure to attend tutorials, and do the weekly readings. The course content itself is interesting but Martin is a bad prof he just rambles on and mumbles. Final was open book but still hard class ave was 58%. Take another prof.

Assignments were very straightforward and I was lucky to have a great TA - got more out of the tutorials than the lectures by far. Lectures were very dense and slides were very text heavy with little to no useful info. Lectures very boring if you're not a philosophy person, so if you took it for a requirement like I did, bring coffee and patience.
final was very difficult but open book. make sure you really prepare for it and write stuff down. good luck

Reads word for word on lecture slides and lacks real life examples or questions. Cheat sheet was allowed for final, so just remember who said what; schools of philosophy; and big ideas for each topic. The TA's were extremely helpful and engaging, so seek help from the TA's instead.

Not necessarily a difficult course but a horrible prof. His slides are incomprehensible, lectures aren't better as he read them word for word and drones on incoherently. Extremely disorganized; typos in slides, emails, study guides, and the freaking exam. Overcomplicates simple philosophy concepts. If you need this, wait for another prof.
Half his slides are filled with grammatical errors and useless examples that just confuse you even more. I would not take this class again even if somebody paid me.

The class material is full of grammatical errors and misspelled words that make it so much more confusing than the information already is. Some of the information and knowledge is interesting; however, the majority is boring. I am most likely going to fail this class. I'm not blaming him, but the material felt as if it wasn't written in English

He does not care for his students. If you try emailing him with a question, he will always reply with "did you not see my other email." For reference, his emails suck and only further complicate matters. The final exam is even worse. The course itself is not curved, but because of the difficulty that students have on the exam, it is always curved.

I enjoyed Martin's lectures for this course. He is a clear and engaging speaker. There were 4-5 small writing assignments and 2 papers - all handled by the TA's. The final exam was difficult, but it was heavily curved. It's a fun class if you are interested in philosophy.

Put together one of the worst final exams I have ever taken. So many spelling mistakes in the questions that it was distracting. We're being assessed on our learning but he doesn't even care enough to proofread the exam.. 10/10 do not recommend.

100W (Fall 2016) was the first philosophy class I have ever taken and Martin was the reason I switched from a biology major to a philosophy major. He is certainly not for everyone - can be a bit hard to follow in lecture sometimes but I thought he chose really interesting readings. Final exam was open book - if you did poorly on it that's on you.
